text: Ellen Bryan Moore (April 13, 1912 – February 20, 1999) was an American politician who served as Louisiana Register of State Lands from 1952 to 1956 and 1960 to 1976. ==Biography== Moore was born in Baton Rouge, Louisiana (where her grandfather served as mayor) on April 13Ellen Bryan Moore's tombstone at Magnolia Cemetery (Baton Rouge, Louisiana), 1912. Her father, Alexander Bryan, had served as the warden of the Louisiana State Penitentiary. She received her bachelor's degree from the Louisiana State University. During World War II, Moore was a member of the Women's Army CorpsOral history interview, abstract available here and was a unit commander. She ran for Louisiana Register of State Lands against Lucille May Grace in 1948,Minden Herald, January 16, 1948, page 2 before finally winning the position in 1952.Minden Press, February 8, 1952, page 1 After Grace took back the seat in 1956, she returned in 1960 and later served until 1976. Her position entailed the responsibility of administrating property owned by the state of Louisiana. She was also a heritage preserver, as was indicated in her efforts to salvage a Civil War battlefield near Baton Rouge. She was inducted to the Louisiana Center for Women in Government and Business Hall of Fame in 1995. After suffering a stroke in October the previous year, she died on February 20, 1999. ==References== Category:1912 births Category:1999 deaths Category:Educators from Louisiana Category:American army personnel of World War II Category:American real estate businesspeople Category:Louisiana Democrats Category:Louisiana State University alumni Category:Politicians from Baton Rouge, Louisiana Category:Registers of the State Land Office of Louisiana Category:United States Army officers Category:University of Louisiana at Lafayette alumni Category:Women in Louisiana politics Category:20th-century American businesspeople Category:Burials at Magnolia Cemetery (Baton Rouge, Louisiana)
title: Ellen Bryan Moore
